PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: David Herbert Magrath
Address: Batchworth, Sask.
Birthplace: Portsmouth, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Alta. 22. 3. 22. 4. 22. (Edmone)
Where had you been living before that? in England
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? Logan's Store about 1 mile from Milne
How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly, usually once every six months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, Sugar, Tea, Rolled Oats, Raisins, Salt, etc. Sometimes Figs in the block.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Strong White
In what quantities did you buy it? Usually 50 lb. at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 75¢
How much did you use graham flour? 1 lb. on Market
Whole wheat flour? 1 lb. on Market
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? 8 qts. $1.25 What year? 1906-07
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 70¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes Whole Wheat? Yes Farina? Yes
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?

Flour, sugar, tea, butter, salt, flour, sugar, tea, butter, salt

By the way, the salmon tasted better when it was canned than it does now.

Sundays, when you had visitors, canned salmon is canned salmon was the order of the day.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) Slough, well.

How far was this water from your home? At well, a few yards.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Slough, by hand.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

You must remember that when we started up the country was as God made it. We got a well dug as soon as we could get at it. Sometime in July 1906. We struck water at 33 ft. One morning. Soon after dinner a CPR survey gang came along & took their Survey right across the field that was the Moore - now Norden. Moore was a Mucklin.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

The fancy wrapping, mostly bulk paper bags. You got your good cheese that way, it was just as good if not better. I think we are paying too much for being silly.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

We had a first rate meal what we could get. Some kind Porridge three times a day. Some Corn-meal clitto. Some bread + Syrup. Babes often went out Sundays to get a meal (don't know). Some times in Summer we had Bread & Wild Strawberries. Meat around meat. Butter burned to oil that we if you had any.

Father 61. Mother 62. Myself 27. My Sister 21.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......1908

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Christmas 1906, deep snow, short of fuel, got under the blankets, sale a packet of raisins between the four of us. That was our Christmas dinner 1906. It was about 40 below. We had all the making but lacked the fuel to cook it.

1907 Family in Battleford. Myself in Summer Camp Hudson Bay Simcoe. 1908. We had Chicken Potatoes, dried green peas & puddin'.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

1906-07 were lean years. Distances too long so great that we had to make do with what we had. If you run short of anything you had to go without. There was no getting by town in the Winter. I knew more than one homesteader put in his clothes on corn-meal mush & water. You didn't see many people those days until well rounded summer.

We were always hungry. Try to put in a 10 hour day behind a working Plow on a Blade Bull or Bread-Jam till. When you are through your sides are hanging in.

P.T.O

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

I don't see very much difference. There may be more variety today—if you can afford to buy it.

We always tried to grow all the vegetables we could.

We were always plain eaters. Didn't go in for the fancy stuff.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We seldom purchased vegetables. If we could not grow them, we went without.

People grumble a great deal about the high cost of living. Well, some of it is their own fault. If you expect other people to purchase your food for you even to the extent I purchased clothing, you have to pay for it.

We grew peas and our own vegetables. We raised our own food.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include back items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Things on the Homestead were very primitive in the first year or two. 1906-07 we had no mail—no newspapers.

So far as what took place in Canada or the World in the years 1906-1907, it was complete blank. We were isolated on the Prairie. The only break was the trip to town—then we were too busy to look at a paper. We only allowed ourselves about a half a day in town, arrive in the morning—sell out before supper. You see you had to think about feed for your animals. You could not get that in town without paying for it.

P.T.C.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and

shopping on the Homestead were very plentiful—no fish

years in hours. 1906-07—had no mail—no newspapers.

In fact we could not have been in Canada or the United States

1906-1907, it was very hard times. We were unable to

buy a thing at first. We only allowed ourselves bread,

butter, a day or two, as a treat. We had no meat or coffee.

Suffice it to say that I think about five or six

times a year I got fed in town and that happens fairly.

P.T.C.
Post Office was set up in the N.E. 15-33-22 W3 in the early spring of 1908. Mail came out from Saskatoon twice a week as far as Borden, P.E. (Plenty) - our PM had his store there for at least 20 miles. Our P.O. was called MacKinnon (Boring). The town was later extended to Borden (Beaufield) - Keller, Marango, also Post Office at Hark (Kirkland), after this time most of us went to Eaton's. Shipping for clothing, hardware, furniture, groceries, etc., we got the goods very reasonable + some good bargains at times. You could get a good suit of clothes for $13.50. Men's boots $2.00, women's shoes $1.50. House linen, good quality $1.00. Pants were anything from 6¢ to 25¢ per yard. Furniture was also reasonable, getting groceries through the mail saved a good many miles of travel to town, which was to a certain extent a waste of time.

The saving gave us more time to work on the land & build improvements as we could afford them. Most often had to build sod shocks to have some place to live, but we were all extremely glad when we could afford some lumber to build a house however small. Wells were also a problem. Shallow wells often dried up sometime early in the summer so you could not keep livestock without water. Some the very early years, we could not do all the breaking up land we would like, but had to take time to get water & building.

Another problem was firing. We used Prairie chips for summer. We had to burn Wood for winter & this had to be gotten in the summer also, as distances were too great to risk getting it in winter. 1906 we got our Wood from Stampede Lakes 1907-8 from the 6 Mile Butte, 45 miles from home. 1909-1910 from Sourkings Lake 39 R6 W4 Alberta 95 miles from farm. What made it more difficult we had to find these places. When we had to look behind the wood & start back home - then we not knew where made them.
